question: What happens to the speed of an earthquake wave when it travels from Earth's crust into the mantle?

content.source_1: Seismic studies show that, at most locations, P-wave velocities increase across the Mohorovičić discontinuity (Moho): from roughly 6–7 km/s in the lower crust to about 7.8–8.2 km/s in the uppermost mantle.
content.source_2: By Snell’s law, when a wave enters a medium in which its speed is higher, the refracted ray bends away from the normal to the interface.
content.source_3: The crust and mantle are distinct solid media with different rock compositions (crust mainly basaltic/granitic; mantle mainly peridotitic silicates), so seismic wave speeds commonly differ across the Moho.
content.source_4: In anomalously hot or partially molten regions just beneath the Moho (e.g., mid-ocean ridges, continental rifts, mantle-plume heads), the uppermost mantle can have unusually low seismic velocities, sometimes comparable to or even lower than those of the lower crust.
content.source_5: When a wave enters a medium in which its speed is lower, the refracted ray bends toward the normal.
content.source_6: Elevated temperature and partial melt reduce seismic wave speeds by lowering rock rigidity (shear modulus).
